colour_scales.Context: The bright pole opposite to melas in light-dark oppositions: static white surfaces; sunlight; bones and teeth
Functions as a brightness marker and is associated with swift movement and brilliance e.g. shining armor and weapons; bright surfaces; lightning; swift dogs
Commonly associated with brightness and nobility, e.g., golden hair of heroes (Menelaus, Achilles); horses and animal manes; fabrics and textiles
Athena's epithet 'glaukopis' – gleaming-eyed, flashing divine power; gleaming sea; reflective metal surfaces
A measure of intensity and motion: burning fire; burning iron (heat of battle); standard description for powerful animals e.g. eagle eyes, darting snake, blazing horses
The soft, diffusing light of Dawn (Eos)

Strongly linked to chatoiement (shimmer), movement, high-status items and metaphorical richness e.g. the sea in motion (surging); royal or aristocratic garments; blood; emotional states; death imagery
Describes a saturated redness e.g. blood; wine
Describes status, wealth and organic richness e.g. royal purple (purple-red dye); flushed complexions
Covers greensih or pale hues, often connoting freshness and vitality (foliage and vegetation); also indicates pallor in human complexion (pale fear)
Denotes texture and age e.g. grey hair ('grey-templed'); sea foam (churned up by a storm); standard epithet for the wolf (polio lykos)
Zeus's dark eyebrows (divine); deep blue pigments, connected to lapis lazuli imagery; painted prow of a ship ('dark-prowed', kyanoproros)
Describes dark richness and sheen, a deep colour or a heavy liquid e.g. heaving, restless sea ('wine-dark sea'); oxen
The dark pole opposite to leukos in light-dark oppositions: darkness and night; black blood; ships (black-tarred hulls); earth

iliad_analysis.Phrase (English): dark [veil], and no garment was blacker than it.

iliad_analysis.Phrase (Ancient Greek): κυάνεον, τοῦ δʼ οὔ τι μελάντερον ἔπλετο ἔσθος.
iliad_analysis.Phrase (English): dark [veil], and no garment was blacker than it.

iliad_analysis.Phrase (Ancient Greek): τόσσα δὲ φάρεα λευκά, τόσους δʼ ἐπὶ τοῖσι χιτῶνας.
iliad_analysis.Phrase (English): and as many white cloaks, and as many tunics besides.

iliad_analysis.Phrase (Ancient Greek): ἐκ δὲ δύʼ αἴθωνας τρίποδας, πίσυρας δὲ λέβητας,
iliad_analysis.Phrase (English): and ten gleaming tripods, and four cauldrons,

iliad_analysis.Phrase (Ancient Greek): τῶν εἴ τίς σε ἴδοιτο θοὴν διὰ νύκτα μέλαιναν
iliad_analysis.Phrase (English): If any of them should see you through the swift black night

iliad_analysis.Phrase (Ancient Greek): οἰκτίρων πολιόν τε κάρη πολιόν τε γένειον,
iliad_analysis.Phrase (English): pitying your grey head and grey beard,

iliad_analysis.Phrase (Ancient Greek): νῦν δὴ καὶ σίτου πασάμην καὶ αἴθοπα οἶνον
iliad_analysis.Phrase (English): Now I have tasted food and [drunk] sparkling wine

iliad_analysis.Phrase (Ancient Greek): πορφύρεʼ ἐμβαλέειν, στορέσαι τʼ ἐφύπερθε τάπητας,
iliad_analysis.Phrase (English): to throw on purple [rugs], and spread carpets on top,

iliad_analysis.Phrase (Ancient Greek): τῶν εἴ τίς σε ἴδοιτο θοὴν διὰ νύκτα μέλαιναν,
iliad_analysis.Phrase (English): If any of them should see you through the swift black night,

iliad_analysis.Phrase (Ancient Greek): τῇσιν δʼ Ἀνδρομάχη λευκώλενος ἦρχε γόοιο
iliad_analysis.Phrase (English): And white-armed Andromache led the lament for them

iliad_analysis.Phrase (Ancient Greek): πέμπων μʼ ὧδʼ ἐπέτελλε μελαινάων ἀπὸ νηῶν
iliad_analysis.Phrase (English): sending me from the black ships, he commanded thus

iliad_analysis.Phrase (Ancient Greek): ἦμος δʼ ἠριγένεια φάνη ῥοδοδάκτυλος Ἠώς,
iliad_analysis.Phrase (English): When early-born, rosy-fingered Dawn appeared,

iliad_analysis.Phrase (Ancient Greek): πρῶτον μὲν κατὰ πυρκαϊὴν σβέσαν αἴθοπι οἴνῳ
iliad_analysis.Phrase (English): First they quenched the pyre with sparkling wine

iliad_analysis.Phrase (Ancient Greek): ὀστέα λευκὰ λέγοντο κασίγνητοί θʼ ἕταροί τε
iliad_analysis.Phrase (English): his brothers and comrades gathered the white bones

iliad_analysis.Phrase (Ancient Greek): πορφυρέοις πέπλοισι καλύψαντες μαλακοῖσιν.
iliad_analysis.Phrase (English): covering them with soft purple robes.
